dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker B
dialogue_turns.text: ...so they've basically said, look, if you want your company listed here, you gotta open up your books to our auditors, right? Within three years, or else.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...so they've basically said, look, if you want your company listed here, you gotta open up your books to our auditors, right? Within three years, or else.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act will require companies to ... allow the U.S. Public Accounting Oversight Board to review their financial audits. ... The companies have a grace period of three years to comply with the requirement before facing the threat of losing access to U.S. stock markets...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, god. Is this more, like, trade war nonsense? Because honestly, I just... I cannot with another round of that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, god. Is this more, like, trade war nonsense? Because honestly, I just... I cannot with another round of that.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, uh, no, I mean, yes, it's Trump, but it actually passed both the House and Senate, like, unanimously. Unanimously! That's... unheard of, almost.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, uh, no, I mean, yes, it's Trump, but it actually passed both the House and Senate, like, unanimously. Unanimously! That's... unheard of, almost.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The measure passed the House by unanimous voice vote after passing the Senate in another unanimous vote in May this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker A
dialogue_turns.text: Unanimous, sure. So everyone can pretend they're tough on China. It's just rhetoric, B. They'll find some way around it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unanimous, sure. So everyone can pretend they're tough on China. It's just rhetoric, B. They'll find some way around it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker B
dialogue_turns.text: But this time it's different. It's not just talk. It means companies like Alibaba, um, Pinduoduo, they literally could get kicked off our stock exchanges. Delisted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But this time it's different. It's not just talk. It means companies like Alibaba, um, Pinduoduo, they literally could get kicked off our stock exchanges. Delisted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the bills measures are clearly intended to target Chinese companies, such as Alibaba Group, Pinduoduo and PetroChina.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker A
dialogue_turns.text: So what? They'll just go somewhere else. Hong Kong, right? Like they're already doing. Yawn.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So what? They'll just go somewhere else. Hong Kong, right? Like they're already doing. Yawn.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In anticipation of the legislation, Chinese companies have pursued secondary listings in Hong Kong as a hedge against the potential ban from trading their shares in the U.S. Alibaba, NetEase and Yum China have already listed their shares in Hong Kong.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! But that's the point, A. Think about American investors. You know, money pouring into those companies, that's now... well, it's going to Hong Kong. Potentially crippling our own investment in the region, some are saying.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! But that's the point, A. Think about American investors. You know, money pouring into those companies, that's now... well, it's going to Hong Kong. Potentially crippling our own investment in the region, some are saying.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker A
dialogue_turns.text: Crippling? Come on. A few tech giants move their paper-shuffling. It's not the end of capitalism as we know it. We'll be fine.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Crippling? Come on. A few tech giants move their paper-shuffling. It's not the end of capitalism as we know it. We'll be fine.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker B
dialogue_turns.text: But it's not just that. The bill actually mandates they verify they're not controlled by a foreign government. And, um, there's even this new Pentagon-led blacklist... companies have to disclose ties to individuals on it. That's a whole new layer.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's not just that. The bill actually mandates they verify they're not controlled by a foreign government. And, um, there's even this new Pentagon-led blacklist... companies have to disclose ties to individuals on it. That's a whole new layer.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act will require companies to establish that they are not owned or controlled by a foreign government...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, yeah, a blacklist. Very original. More government bureaucracy, that's all I hear. What's next, they'll make them sing the national anthem?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, yeah, a blacklist. Very original. More government bureaucracy, that's all I hear. What's next, they'll make them sing the national anthem?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker B
dialogue_turns.text: No, but it also, like, could actually mess with Biden's climate agenda. If these companies are delisted, that's less leverage for, you know, green initiatives with China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, but it also, like, could actually mess with Biden's climate agenda. If these companies are delisted, that's less leverage for, you know, green initiatives with China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker A
dialogue_turns.text: Biden's climate agenda? Oh, please. Every single thing is going to mess with Biden's climate agenda, B. It's not this particular bill. It's everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Biden's climate agenda? Oh, please. Every single thing is going to mess with Biden's climate agenda, B. It's not this particular bill. It's everything.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker B
dialogue_turns.text: But this is a concrete, tangible *thing* that has, um, real-world ramifications for our markets. And China's already threatening global investor confidence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But this is a concrete, tangible thing that has, um, real-world ramifications for our markets. And China's already threatening global investor confidence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Before the U.S. President had signed the bill, Chinas Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying told reporters, It will undermine global investors confidence in the U.S. capital markets and will undermine the U.S. capital markets global standing and hurt U.S. interests.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker A
dialogue_turns.text: Investor confidence. Yeah, like that's ever been stable for more than five minutes anyway. Look, it's just another squabble. Business finds a way, it always does.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Investor confidence. Yeah, like that's ever been stable for more than five minutes anyway. Look, it's just another squabble. Business finds a way, it always does.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker B
dialogue_turns.text: I just feel like... it's a big shift, you know? The whole, uh, financial landscape.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I just feel like... it's a big shift, you know? The whole, uh, financial landscape.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker A
dialogue_turns.text: A big shift that'll probably just result in a slightly different set of acronyms for us to ignore. Call me when actual money is on fire.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A big shift that'll probably just result in a slightly different set of acronyms for us to ignore. Call me when actual money is on fire.
